none: Fāʾida of the Ten-by-Ten Number Square (Anonymous, c. 19th century)
Translated title: Fāʼidah of the ten-by-ten number squares
ʻUmar Falke Collection (Melville J. Herskovits Library of African Studies) (Contributor)
Part of the Maktaba grant project (Local Note)
In Arabic in Maghrebi style script. (Language Note)
Arabic Manuscripts from West Africa--The ‘Umar Falke Collection

A fāʾida (a genre of text offering specific recipes, practices, or actions that promise the user assistance in times of need) from northern Nigeria dating from the late nineteenth or early twentieth centuries. This fāʾida instructs the user to employ a ten-by-ten number square to achieve their desires.

The images on this web site are from material in the collections of the Melville J. Herskovits Library of African Studies at Northwestern University Libraries, are provided for use by its students, faculty and staff, and by other researchers visiting this site, for research consultation and scholarly purposes only. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of the images from this site is not permitted.
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

This rare collection of manuscripts dates back to the 19th and 20th centuries and come from mainly northern Nigeria (Kano in particular) but also includes items from Ghana, Senegal and Mali. Mostly handwritten in Arabic and Ajami scripts, these manuscripts cover a wide range of subjects from Arabic grammar, history, theology, law and astronomy to name a few, with particular strength in Tijâniyya Sufi order and Hausa poetry.   Comprised of 5,000 items, the manuscripts are split across four separate collections and serve as an excellent example of West African literacy in Arabic:  The 'Umar Falke Collection, The John Paden Collection, The John Hunwick Collection, The University of Ghana Collection

body.value:
*Translated by Paul Naylor* 

In the name of God, the Most Gracious the Most Merciful. God's blessings upon he after whom there will be no other Prophet.

*Fāʾida* of the ten-by-ten number square. The number[^1] of Sūrat Yūsuf and Sūrat Yā-sīn with "When the Inevitable Event takes place"[^2] and "The Striking Disaster!"[^3] and "Have We not uplifted"[^4] with the names of *al-Burda*, *al-Ishrīnīyāt* and *Dalāʾil al-khayrāt*.[^5] Add up their number in a ten-by-ten number square of great power.

And whoever encounters this square has achieved a great achievement. It is a secret to achieving one's desire. It is related from ʿAlī ibn Abī Ṭālib that whoever carries this amulet or writes it and drinks it and washes with it will never encounter tragedy in this world and will go out into the world safe. And whoever writes it and gives it to a powerful person, if he sees his enemy he will defeat him upon meeting him. And whoever writes it and attaches it to the son of the ruler, he will inherit the rule of his father. And whoever drinks it when asking for love, everyone will love him intensely if God wills, and [give him] respect, acceptance, money, and kind words, and he will see good fortune come to him. And whoever attaches it to the traveler, even if he walks for many years he will return safe and with much wealth when he returns. And whoever wants to have much wealth and be rich through business, he is to write this amulet and drink it with honey and fresh milk and he will be wealthy. He will find the wealth of the world until he does not even know how much money he has if God wills. He will never lose any of his money and the blessing of his money will increase. And whoever attaches it will not see disaster on land or sea if God wills. And whoever drinks it once or twice or three times---whoever drinks it like this---God will gather the world at his door and it will be like a marketplace[^6] if God wills. He will find strength among God's creatures and generosity, status, and respect, and God will make him victorious against his enemies with the protection of the Prophet. Whoever wears it will see God's miracles and see many good things until he says often: "Praise be to God and thanks to God's grace." And this is the amulet. Do not give it to the impatient person for God and His messenger will make him blind. And do not give it to anyone except in exchange for a lot of money. Praise be to God and His Messenger, it is complete.

[^1]: That is, the equivalent of the sum of all the letters in the suras and the book titles mentioned.

[^2]: Qurʾan 56:1, i.e., with Sūrat al-Wāqiʿa. English translations of the Qurʾan are from Mustafa Khattab, *The Clear Quran: A Thematic English Translation of the Message of the Final Revelation* (Lombard, IL: Book of Signs Foundation, 2016).

[^3]: Qurʾan 101:1, i.e., with Sūrat al-Qāriʿa.

[^4]: Qurʾan 94:1, i.e., with Sūrat al-Sharḥ.

[^5]: Popular poems or prayers praising Prophet Muhammad.

[^6]: That is, "it will be full of people." Probably a calque from Hausa, where "having many people" means having influence.

بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم صلى الله على من لا نبي بعده الكريم فائدة الخواتم معشر  

فائدة وعدد سورة يوسف وسورة يسين وإذا وقعت الواقعة 

والقارعة وألم نشرح مع اسم البردة والعشريني والدلائل الخيرات 

وتجمع عددهم في وفق المعشر جليله القدر ومن وجد هذا الخاتم 

فقد فاز فوزا عظيما وهو سرا لبلغ المنى وهو غاية الغاية وروي 

عن علي بن ابي طالب رضي الله عنه قال من حمل هذا الخاتم أو كتبه وشربه 

وغسله لا يرى مصيبة الدنيا حتى يخرج في الدنيا سالما ومن 

كتبه وعطر وصاحب العز وإذا يرى عدوه يهزمون عند لقائه 

ومن كتبه وعلقه على ولد السلطان يجد الملك أبيه ومن شر 

به على عند طلب المحبة يحبه الجماعة حبا شديدا بإذن الله  

والهيبة والقبول والمال والكلام طيبة ويرى خيرا في شربه  

ومن علّقه المسافر ولو مشى عاما كبيرا يرجع سالما والمال  

كثيرا معه إذا يرجع ومن أراد أن يكون كثير المال غني  

عن تاجر فليكتب هذا الخاتم ويشربه مع العسل ولبن رطب 

يكون مرزوقا وجد المال الدنيا حتى لا يعلم عدده في ماله إن شاء الله تعالى  

ولا يخسر خسرانا في ماله ويزيد البركة  

بماله ومن علقه لا يرى مصيبه البر والبحر إن شاء الله تعالى 

ومن شربه واحدا أو اثنين أو ثلاث ومن شرب هكذا فإنه 

يجمع الله الدنيا بداره كثيرا ويكون كاسوق إن شاء 

الله ويجد القدرة بين الخلائق والكرامة والدرجة والهيبة  

ونصره الله على أعدائه بحرمه النبي ومن حامله يرى عجبا  

من عجائب الله ويرى خيرا كثيرا حتى يقول الحمد لله  

واشكر على نعمة الله كثيرا وهذا الخاتم لا يعطيه لمن  

لا صبر له على الله ورسوله ولا يعطيه لأحد إلا بالمال  

جزيلا الحمد لله انتهى الكلام على الله ورسوله تمت

In the Name of God the Most Gracious the Most Merciful. God's blessings upon he after whom there will be no other Prophet.

God, there is no God but Him

O Living One, O Everlasting

Drowsiness does not overtake Him[^7]

[^7]: Qurʾan 2:255. This text, on side b, is likely the vessel referred to in the *fāʾida*. Each passage has a greatly elongated line joining the middle letters.

بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم صلى الله على من لا نبي بعده الكريم 

الله لا إلــــــــــــــــــــــــه إلا هو 

 الحي القيـــــــــــــــــــــــــــــوم 

لا تاخــــــــــــــــــــــــــــــذه سنة
